definitions: add an extra charge or fee on top of the standard cost
load with excessive weight or burden beyond normal capacity
examples: The airline will surcharge passengers for overweight luggage
Credit card companies often surcharge for international transactions
The truck was surcharged with cargo beyond its limit
Don't surcharge the electrical circuit with too many devices

definitions: ride on breaking waves toward the shore using a board
search through websites or channels looking for interesting content
examples: They surf the biggest waves during winter storms
He learned to surf on the gentle waves of Waikiki
She likes to surf the web during her lunch break
Teenagers often surf social media for hours each day

definitions: come up to the top of water or another liquid
become known or visible after being hidden or unnoticed
cover something with a particular material to create a smooth finish
examples: The submarine will surface near the island at dawn
Whales surface every few minutes to breathe fresh air
New evidence surfaced during the investigation last week
Old conflicts surface when the family gets together
They need to surface the road before winter arrives
The contractor will surface the driveway with new asphalt

definitions: travel across water on a surfboard riding waves
examples: She surfboards every morning before going to work
Professional athletes surfboard in competitions around the world

definitions: move suddenly and powerfully forward in a strong wavelike motion
increase suddenly and dramatically in amount, number, or intensity
examples: The crowd surged forward when the gates finally opened
Ocean waves surge against the rocky cliffs during storms
Electricity demand surges during the hottest days of summer
Stock prices surged after the positive earnings report

definitions: form an opinion or conclusion without certain evidence or proof
examples: Scientists surmise that the asteroid impact caused mass extinction
From her expression, I surmised she wasn't pleased with the results

definitions: perform better than someone or something in quality or achievement
go beyond what was expected or what seemed possible
examples: This year's sales surpass all previous company records
The student surpassed her teacher's expectations completely
The final cost will surpass our original budget significantly
Technology continues to surpass what we thought was possible

definitions: cause someone to feel amazement or shock by something unexpected
attack or discover someone suddenly when they are not expecting it
examples: The birthday party will surprise her when she gets home
His decision to retire early surprised everyone at work
Enemy forces surprised the camp just before dawn broke
Police surprised the burglars while they were still inside

definitions: stop fighting and admit defeat or give up control to another
allow yourself to be overcome by a powerful emotion or influence
examples: The army will surrender after months of fierce fighting
The suspect surrendered to police without any resistance
She finally surrendered to exhaustion and fell asleep immediately
Don't surrender to despair when facing difficult challenges

definitions: position things or people all around something forming a circle
exist or be present all around something in the environment
examples: Police officers surround the building preventing anyone from escaping
They surrounded the campfire telling stories until midnight
Mountains surround the valley creating a natural protective barrier
Mystery still surrounds the circumstances of her sudden disappearance

definitions: look at or examine something carefully and comprehensively
investigate opinions or behavior by questioning a group of people
measure and map an area of land for construction or mapping
examples: The inspector will survey the damage from yesterday's storm
She surveyed the room looking for familiar faces
Researchers survey thousands of voters before each major election
The company surveys customer satisfaction every three months
Engineers must survey the site before construction can begin
They hired professionals to survey their property boundaries accurately

definitions: continue to live despite danger, hardship, or life-threatening situation
continue to exist or remain functional despite difficult circumstances
live longer than another person, typically a family member
examples: Only three passengers survived the terrible plane crash yesterday
Plants can't survive without water for very long periods
The ancient tradition survives in remote mountain villages today
Few small businesses survive their first five years of operation
She survived her husband by nearly twenty years
He survived all his siblings despite being the oldest

definitions: believe someone is guilty of a crime or wrongdoing without proof
think something is probable or likely to be true
examples: Police suspect him of stealing valuable jewelry from the store
Neighbors suspected something was wrong when newspapers piled up
I suspect she already knows about the surprise party
Doctors suspect the infection spread from contaminated water sources

definitions: hang something from above so it dangles freely in space
temporarily stop or delay an activity, process, or privilege
temporarily prevent someone from participating in an activity as punishment
examples: They suspend delicate ornaments from the ceiling with fishing line
The bridge was suspended between two massive stone towers
The company will suspend production during the holiday season
Officials suspended all flights due to severe weather conditions
The school suspended three students for violating dress code
The league suspended the player for unsportsmanlike conduct

definitions: maintain or continue something at the same level over time
experience or suffer injury, damage, or loss, especially in formal contexts
bear the weight of something or keep it from falling
examples: The organization cannot sustain these losses for much longer
Plants sustain themselves through photosynthesis and water absorption
The building sustained significant damage during the earthquake yesterday
Several passengers sustained minor injuries in the collision
These pillars sustain the entire weight of the roof
The bridge can sustain loads up to fifty tons

definitions: surgically stitch together the edges of a wound or incision
examples: The surgeon will suture the incision after removing the appendix
Emergency room doctors sutured the deep cut on his forehead

definitions: clean or wipe something with an absorbent cloth or cotton
collect a sample from a surface using a cotton swab
examples: Nurses swab the injection site with alcohol before giving shots
Sailors swab the deck every morning to keep it clean
Technicians swab surfaces to test for bacterial contamination
The nurse will swab your throat to test for infection

definitions: walk with an arrogant or confident swaying movement
arrange fabric or garlands in decorative curved hanging folds
examples: He swags around the office acting like he owns the place
The pirates swagged down the dock carrying their treasure
They swagged the windows with elegant velvet curtains for the party
Decorators swag greenery along the staircase during the holidays

definitions: walk or behave in a very confident and arrogant manner
examples: The champion swaggered into the ring with complete confidence
He swaggers around campus like he's better than everyone else

definitions: cause food or drink to pass down the throat to stomach
completely surround, envelop, or cause to disappear into something
accept or believe something difficult or unpleasant without protest
examples: Children should chew their food thoroughly before they swallow
The patient couldn't swallow pills without water to help
The massive sinkhole swallowed three cars in the parking lot
Darkness swallowed the landscape as the sun set completely
She had to swallow her pride and apologize publicly
Investors swallowed their losses and moved on to new ventures

definitions: flood or soak an area with water making it impassable
overwhelm with too much of something, especially work or problems
examples: Heavy rains swamped the lowland areas causing major flooding
The storm surge swamped several coastal communities last night
Customer complaints swamped the help desk after the outage
Don't let minor details swamp the main message

definitions: move about in a leisurely, relaxed, or aimless way
examples: She swans around the office chatting instead of working
They swanned through Europe for three months after graduating

definitions: display one's wealth, knowledge, or achievements in a boastful way
examples: He loves to swank about his expensive cars and yacht
She swanks her designer clothes at every social event

definitions: give something and receive something else in return through mutual agreement
examples: The children swap trading cards during lunch break every day
Let's swap seats so you can see the stage better

definitions: move somewhere in large numbers as a densely packed group
be crowded or filled with moving people, animals, or things
examples: Bees swarm when they leave the hive to establish new colonies
Tourists swarm the beaches during the summer vacation months
The plaza swarms with vendors selling local handicrafts daily
Mosquitoes swarm around the porch light every summer evening

definitions: move water or liquid about vigorously making splashing sounds
examples: Waves swash against the hull of the sailing boat
Water swashed in the bucket as he carried it quickly

definitions: hit something sharply with a quick blow, especially to kill insects
examples: She swatted the mosquito that landed on her arm
The cat swatted at the dangling string with its paw

definitions: wrap someone or something in several layers of fabric or bandages
examples: Nurses swathe newborn babies in soft blankets for warmth
The mummy was swathed in ancient linen burial cloths

definitions: move slowly or rhythmically backward and forward or side to side
influence someone to change their opinion, decision, or actions
examples: Palm trees sway gently in the tropical ocean breeze
The tall building sways slightly during strong wind storms
His emotional speech swayed many voters to support his campaign
Don't let peer pressure sway your important life decisions

definitions: use offensive or obscene language, especially to express anger
make a solemn promise or statement affirming something is true
give evidence or make a statement under oath in legal proceedings
examples: He swears whenever he gets frustrated with technology problems
Parents told their children not to swear at school
I swear I'll never tell anyone your secret
She swears by this remedy for treating common colds
Witnesses must swear to tell the truth in court
The president swears an oath of office during inauguration

definitions: produce moisture through the skin pores when hot or nervous
work extremely hard physically or mentally with great effort
be anxious or worried about something causing mental stress
examples: Athletes sweat profusely during intense training sessions in summer
I always sweat when speaking in front of large audiences
Construction workers sweat in the hot sun all day long
Students sweat over their final exams every semester
Don't sweat the small stuff that doesn't really matter
He's sweating about the job interview tomorrow morning

definitions: clean a floor or area by brushing away dirt with a broom
move swiftly and smoothly in a particular direction or manner
win all the games, prizes, or contests in a competition
examples: She sweeps the kitchen floor every morning after breakfast
Janitors sweep the hallways after school ends each day
The storm swept through the valley destroying everything in its path
She swept into the room wearing an elegant evening gown
The home team swept the series winning all four games
The film swept the awards winning every major category

definitions: become larger or rounder in size, typically from internal pressure
rise and fall rhythmically or in waves, especially of water
examples: Her ankle swelled badly after she twisted it playing soccer
The river swells dangerously during the spring snow melt
Ocean waves swell before crashing onto the sandy beach
The music swelled to a dramatic crescendo at the finale

definitions: change direction suddenly, especially to avoid hitting something while moving
examples: The driver swerved to avoid hitting the deer on the road
The cyclist had to swerve around the pothole quickly

definitions: propel oneself through water using arms and legs
experience a dizzy, confused sensation where everything seems to move
examples: Children learn to swim at the community pool every summer
Dolphins swim alongside boats in the warm ocean waters
My head swims whenever I stand up too quickly
The room seemed to swim after the roller coaster ride

definitions: obtain money or property from someone through fraud or deception
examples: Con artists swindled elderly victims out of their life savings
The company swindled investors with promises of huge returns

definitions: move back and forth or from side to side while suspended
change suddenly from one position, opinion, or mood to another
move something in a wide curve or arc to hit something
examples: Children love to swing on the playground during recess time
The pendulum swings steadily marking each passing second
Public opinion swings wildly during election campaign seasons
His mood swings from happy to angry without warning
The batter swung at the fastball but missed completely
She swung her bag at the attacker in self-defense

definitions: hit or try to hit something with a swinging motion
steal something quickly and often without being noticed
pass a card through an electronic reader to process payment
examples: The cat swiped at the toy mouse with its paw
The bear swiped at the camper with its massive claws
Someone swiped my phone while I wasn't paying attention
Kids often swipe cookies from the jar before dinner
Please swipe your credit card to complete the purchase
Employees swipe their badges to enter the secure building

definitions: move in a twisting or spiraling pattern, especially of liquids or gases
examples: Cream swirls beautifully when poured into hot coffee
Autumn leaves swirl in the wind before settling on ground

definitions: move with a soft rustling or hissing sound through air or water
examples: Her silk dress swishes as she walks down the hallway
The horse's tail swishes to keep the flies away

definitions: change from one thing to another different thing or option
exchange positions, directions, or roles with someone or something
examples: Many people switch careers multiple times during their working lives
She decided to switch from coffee to tea for health reasons
The dancers switch partners every few minutes during practice
Let's switch seats so you can see better

definitions: turn around a central point or axis while remaining fixed in place
examples: Office chairs swivel to allow workers to reach different areas
She swiveled her head to look at the sudden noise

definitions: faint or lose consciousness from extreme emotion or physical weakness
be overcome with extreme admiration, pleasure, or romantic feelings
examples: Victorian ladies would swoon at shocking news or events
She nearly swooned from the heat and lack of fresh air
Teenagers swoon over their favorite pop stars at concerts
Critics swooned over the director's latest masterpiece film

definitions: move rapidly downward through the air, especially to attack
carry out a sudden raid or attack to seize something
examples: The eagle swooped down to catch the fish from the lake
Bats swoop through the evening sky catching insects
Police swooped on the building arresting several suspects immediately
Investors swooped in to buy the undervalued company shares

definitions: be a symbol of something or represent something through symbolic meaning
examples: The dove symbolises peace in many cultures around the world
These ancient artifacts symbolise the power of past rulers

definitions: be a symbol of something or represent something through symbolic meaning
examples: Wedding rings symbolize eternal love and commitment between partners
The flag symbolizes our nation's values and shared history

definitions: feel or express compassion for someone's suffering or misfortune
agree with or understand someone's feelings, opinions, or position
examples: Friends sympathize with her during this difficult time of loss
I sympathize with anyone struggling to find affordable housing
Many citizens sympathize with the protesters' demands for change
I sympathize with your frustration about the delayed project

definitions: synchronize digital data between two or more devices or systems
cause things to occur or operate at the same time or rate
examples: Your phone will sync contacts with your computer automatically
Make sure to sync your files before leaving the office
The dancers need to sync their movements with the music
Audio and video must sync perfectly in the final edit

definitions: cause things to occur or operate at the same time or rate
update data across multiple systems to maintain consistency
examples: Swimmers must synchronize their movements for the team routine
The traffic lights synchronize to improve traffic flow downtown
The system synchronizes user data across all connected devices
Companies synchronize their databases every night for consistency

definitions: form a group of individuals or organizations for a joint business project
publish or broadcast material simultaneously in multiple newspapers or stations
examples: Several investors syndicate to purchase the expensive property together
Banks often syndicate large loans to spread the risk
Major newspapers syndicate popular comic strips to smaller papers
The company syndicates content to hundreds of radio stations
